div1.opener: Entract of Royal Decree of 21st October 1880
div1.p: Having heard the Council of the Foreign Office and the Cabinet Council I have decreed the following:
Article 1: A tonnage due is hereby established in the Colonies of Portugal certable on Foreign National Vessel either or Ocean going or Coasting in the manner prescribed in the following Articles.

Article 2: National or foreign vessels either sailing or steam entering her ports of the portuguese colonial provinces are subject to the tonnage dues laid down in the Table signed by the Minister and Secretary of Marine & Coloners

This due is collected by the Custom House of the first port of the Colonial Province or by the "Rasto Fiscal" where there
there is no Custom House. The vessel containing the same voyage can enter any other port or ports of the said Province without paying fresh tonnage dues.
Article 3: All dues that may now be in force collected on Foreign or National Vessels in the ports of the Colonial Provinces under the title of Anchorage, tonnage or light dues are hereby revoked.

Provisional Article: The rules established in the port of Moacan with regard to the dues actually collected on shipping and the mode of collection remain provisionally in force: the stepulations of this decree, however, applies to all, other shipping to which, on the date of publication of the said decree in the Gazetter of Moacan, shall not have been applied the system of licences, agreements, and
and other rules in force

Table of Tonnage dues referred to in Article 2 of this Decree Ocean going sailing vessels per Reis Ton measurement = 2m 83 150 $0.15cts Ocean going steam ships per ton measurement 50. 5 Ocean going Steam ships plying regularly between the Metropolis and the Colonial provinces per ton measurnment 25. 2 1/2 Coasting vessels in each Province per ton measurement, and only once a year counting from date of each payment 150. 15
Exemptions: The following are not subject to Tonnage dues: Vessels of War of whatever nacionality- Merchant vessels compelled by stress of weather to enter any of the Colonial ports.

Merchant vessels, leaving special Contract or by International
International Treaties and special laws are exempt from payment of the said dues.
Foreign or National Vessels employed exclusively in fishing
Secretary of State for Marine & Colonial affairs
